awd_titl_txt: Consenting to searches and the 4th Amendment:   Situated social cognition within the "totality of circumstances" analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Under the 4th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, people have the fundamental right to be free from unreasonable searches. A search does not violate the 4th Amendment when a person voluntarily consents to be searched, and people routinely and frequently consent to police requests to search.  The reasons why people consent to police searches, even when they are in possession of illegal material, are poorly understood.  As a result, it is difficult for courts to assess voluntariness of consent in a systematic way. The purpose of this research is to identify factors that influence the voluntariness of consents and to identify factors that may increase coercion to consent. Situated cognition is a psychological theory arguing that the social and physical situation in which events occur can affect how a person perceives an event and behaves during an event.  This project will apply situated social cognition to the consent search situation to determine what aspects of the social and physical situation in which the consent search takes place might make people more likely to feel coerced to consent. Across a series of studies, the influence of situational factors will be investigated such as the physical environment (size of the search space, lighting and temperature), the relative physical positions of the searcher and person being searched, and the physical and psychological connection between the person and the property being searched.  The research will be conducted by creating a situation in which a request to search will be made. 

This new application of situated social cognition to the legal system will advance the theory generally, making the research important theoretically. The results of this research will provide important information to courts in their consideration of consent searches which will be essential to the protection of fundamental Constitutional rights.

por.por_cntn:
The research in the grant “Consenting to searches and the 4th Amendment: Situated social cognition within the ‘totality of circumstances’ analysis” investigated how variations in a searchees’ knowledge of their rights, in the physical search situation, and in the social search situation affect consent rates and perceptions of the search. Situated social cognition is a theory predicting that variations in physical and social situations might affect how people perceive those situations and make decisions about them. In a series of studies, a situation was created in which a request to search a participant’s bag for evidence of cheating on the research task was made. Within that search situation, several situated social cognition factors that might affect consent decisions were varied. In Study 1, we investigated the effect of knowledge (a lesson on Constitutional rights and a warning that consent can be denied). In Study 2, we investigated the effect of the physical environment (lighting, temperature, and size of search space). In Study 3, we investigated the effect of the social environment (exit-blocking, closeness, and relative vertical positions). In Study 4, we investigated the effect of item ownership and physical proximity (ownership of item, proximity to item). In Study 5, we combined factors from previous studies that have implications for police procedures (warnings, exit-blocking/closeness, proximity to item). 

Across all of these studies, a consistent effect was that a high rate (91%) of people consented to be searched on average (with a range of 82%-97% across studies), similar to consent rates from actual police searches. None of the variations in the search situation affected these consent rates. However, the situational factors affected how people felt about the search request and about their consent decisions, consistent with the theory of situated social cognition. For example, people felt their consent was more voluntary, they were in more control of the consent decision, and they were freer to leave when the physical environment was cold. They felt their consent was more voluntary when both they and the search requestor were standing than when the search requestor was standing over them. Providing a warning that the searchee has the right to say “no” to the search made people feel freer to leave and feel less pressure to say “yes.” Variations in the search situation also impacted people’s emotional reactions to the search request. Negative emotions increased when the searchee’s exit was blocked, when their own property was searched, when they were separated from their property, and when the search space was warm, brightly lit, and small. Overall, these results indicate that subtle changes in the search request context can impact the voluntariness of consent in ways that might not be obvious when only considering whether the person consented or not. 

This research was the first to examine consent search decision making in a controlled lab environment. It used a novel research approach to study a difficult, real-world problem. The results of this research extend the theory of situated social cognition into the consent search context, providing evidence that the theory can help explain people’s perceptions of the search request. Although none of the situated social cognition factors affected consent rates, they impacted how people perceived the search situation and their emotional reactions to the search situation in ways that were consistent with the theory. These results advance the area of situated social cognition research in general and successfully expand its application into a new area. Additionally, this research previously unknown information about what factors might affect people making consent search decisions. 

These results have broader impacts for police procedures and for courts assessing the voluntariness of consents to search. Police may want to consider providing a warning to searchees about their right to say “no” to a consent search. Police also may want to consider how procedures like cornering a searchee and separating them from the searched property might affect consent. The results highlight some factors that courts could consider when assessing the voluntariness of a criminal defendant’s consent to be searched by the police. Regardless of whether consent was given, courts may want to examine the social and physical situation in which the search took place when assessing the voluntariness of that consent under the “totality of the circumstances.” Finally, the grant provided scientific research training opportunities to a broad array of graduate and undergraduate students, many of whom were from groups underrepresented in the scientific community.
